abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is satisfactory, sustainability is highly
            likely, institutional development impact is substantial,
            Bank performance is satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            is highly satisfactory. These were some of the lessons
            learned from this project. The project outcomes confirmed an
            experience from Romania and Russia, that severance as seed
            capital failed to result in an appreciable level of
            development activity (new businesses were not created). This
            was partially due to the fact that the amount of severance
            was limited, and partially due to an insufficient assistance
            to new business entities. Another lesson learned is that the
            administration of social support programs for workers being
            displaced is best centered in one agency that has a direct
            interest to ensure that the program operates. The most
            successful labor redeployment program was the retraining
            program. Structural unemployment experienced by displaced
            workers, who lack skills or whose skills are not in demand,
            and who need to retool their skills to compete and re-enter
            the labor market can be helped by different types of
            retraining, including on-the-job training and institutional
            training needed in these circumstances. The user-fee system
            will probably exclude some people from the training.
            However, many people can afford to pay the fees and are
            willing to invest resources in increasing the value of their
            human capital. The temporary community employment program
            had an impact on employment. However, this impact was
            achieved at a very high unit cost. Therefore it is
            questionable whether the temporary community employment
            program should form part of any future active labor programs
            in Macedonia. The small business assistance programs have
            unfulfilled potential. Integrating the assistance they
            provide with other measures and programs to provide access
            to credit could therefore be considered. An active public
            information campaign also contributed to the success of the
            project. In a politically volatile environment in which the
            leadership of key implementing agencies is rapidly changing,
            the continuity of Project Coordination Unit staff can be key
            for the project success. Project implementation would
            benefit if the differences in Bank and Borrower's
            procurement rules and laws are identified at an earlier
            stage, and if necessary, amendments to national laws are proposed.

5084607.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Support Project will help
            mitigate the negative social and economic impact of
            bankruptcy, and, labor restructuring of the Majority State
            Owned Enterprises (MSOEs), as well as, the emergency
            economic disruption, due to the conflict in Kosovo. Within
            the strategic context, the project will support the
            completion of enterprises privatization, and, will focus on
            poverty alleviation and human capital development, by
            targeting social assistance programs, and, upgrading social
            services. The main project components will include: 1) labor
            restructuring, to be financed through severance payments -
            regulated by law - for those workers displaced by bankruptcy
            or MSOEs' restructuring. In addition, social
            monitoring, will ensure needed social services are met.
            Limited assistance will be provided to develop employment
            services; 2) labor redeployment, which will facilitate those
            workers who, were either displaced due to labor
            restructuring or the conflict in Kosovo, or, are long-term
            unemployed, or first time job seekers, into the labor force.
            An administrative framework will be established, enabling
            government agencies to provide organizational services, as
            needed, for redeployment issues; 3) social benefits, to
            improve social programs effectiveness, and, develop
            institutional capacity, to evaluate social protection and
            labor market programs; and, 4) project management, to ensure
            an effective administration.
